reviewSubItems.name: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone
Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban
Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix
Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows

name: A Song of Ice and Fire
The Heroes of Olympus
review: This was actually my first time entering the Percy Jackson universe as I was gifted the first 2 books by a friend. I hadn't read the og Percy Jackson series which all of these books were based on.

name: Trials of Apollo
review: The first 3 books were decent. It's set after the Heroes of Olympus events so there's plenty of references and interactions with characters we already know about. I think those were the best part of the series. The concept of a god becoming an immortal and losing all his powers was interesting, however I didn't find the character of Apollo that likeable. The same goes with the other Protagonist, but I do give credit for putting a demigod of Demeter in the spotlight which some really unique plant abilities which we didn't see in previous series. He was quite annoying at times by being a little too incompetent. I wasn't interested enough to read the last book but the cameos from characters we already know about were the best, such as Percy and Leo and how they're going on with life after the huge events in the Heroes of Olympus series.

name: The Kane Chronicles
review: This series didn't get me hooked like Percy Jackson did. Although I don't think the series is bad by any means, it just felt like a copy of Percy Jackson but under a different mythological universe where there's an unsuspecting hero that suddenly gets placed into an unfamiliar world and is responsible for major events.

name: Magnus Chase and the Gods of Asgard
review: Likewise with The Kane Chronicles, it does just wasn't as engaging as the Percy Jackson serie and felt inferior in most aspects. The world building and Valhalla is still really interesting but it wasn't enough to get me to read the entire series.

name: The Inheritance Cycle
review: This book is definitely one of the personal favourites for me because i've read it multiple times. Although I wouldn't say the book has really complex plots, it is really enjoyable to read as the character and world building is still really great. Sometimes good versus evil is enough to be entertaining. The main protagonists and other point of view characters are all really likeable and unique in their pesonalities. I also like the focus on how all the races view the world very differently, especially the political and cultural behaviours. I felt like I had gone on one enormous journey and grown alongside the characters as they overcame their struggles and weaknesses.

name: A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms
review: A prequel to the main ASOIAF series, this book consists of 3 novellas about the adventures of 2 characters. The great thing is that this book does well as a standalone series, while only being set in the Game of Thrones universe. It's great to see characters dealing with more 'local' problems rather than being overshadowed by a greater plot that will affect the entirity of Westeros. However, there is still plenty of references to famous houses and events that readers will know from the other books which also adds to the immersion in the world. It's also considerably smaller and less dense than the ASOIAF books which also makes it an easy read that takes less time to digest the plot. There is honestly nothing I can really fault with this novel which is why I'm giving it a 10.

name: Dune Chronicles
review: I discovered the book series after watching the movie which I really enjoyed. It's cool to have read something that really inspired a lot of people media today such as Star Wars. This is definitely a very challenging read that tackles some really fundamental human experiences in a complex way. I did find myself a lot of the time having to re-read paragraphs to really try and understand what was happening and sometimes I was not able to figure it out. But I think this may have also been part of the author's intention, to not explain every single bit of lore in the world but provide enough information to picture the world for ourselves.

After the first book is where it got extremely difficult to follow the plot and plans of all the different characters. I had to search online for summaries and explanations just to understand the basic premise. I wasn't able to finish the 3rd book which is where I left the series due to the sheer challenge of understanding it. The first book was the best as I could still follow along, but I'm not giving it as high of a rating because of how difficult it is to read.

name: Different Seasons
review: This was my first time reading something by Stephen King. It is a collection of short stories that seemed like a good read in a short amount of time. I was surprised to learn that the movie Shawshank Redemption is based off a novella in this book. I was not able to get through the 3rd story which was 'The Body' and that was where I left this book. Overall the stories I did get through were excellent and engaging.

reviewSubItems.name: Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption
review: A short but entertaining read which kept me engaged the whole way through. But I have to admit, the movie tells the story in the best way possible with a perfect cast even though the adaptation to the book is almost identical

reviewSubItems.name: Apt Pupil
review: This was a surprisingly great story with a plot I did not expect at all. It started off pretty slow, but after some more interactions between the 2 main characters the story really kicks off. It's interesting to see how the relationship between the school kid and former Nazi devolves further and further into insanity. It reaches the point where both characters recognise the conflict they have but continue to commit more unspeakable acts until there is no turning back.

reviewSubItems.name: Avatar
review: The CGI in this movie is ground breaking for something that's from 2009. The world itself is always a spectacle to look at.

reviewSubItems.name: Avatar: The Way of the Water
review: 100% worth the long wait to see this movie in 3D Vmax. The visuals are the most stunning I have ever seen in the movie, and there is no point in the movie in which immersion is broken. CGI Water is something that is extremely difficult to get looking realistic and in this movie it makes the world and universe seem completely realistic. Although the story was not as engaging (might have dragged on a little too long towards the end), it was still good and made up for by the cinematography. I would still watch all the future movies just for the visuals, even if the story isn't perfect.

name: Interstellar
review: By far the best movie i've ever watched and was lucky enough to have viewed it on IMAX for the first time. I really enjoy the sci-fi genre and coupling that with an emotionally deep story was amazing. What really makes the movie in my opinion is the score by Hans Zimmer, it makes every moment infinitely more immersive and intense. It took me a couple of watches to realise that the focus of the story is actually on the love between a father and daughter surpassing time and space. I believe this is what gives the movie lots of rewatchability and meaning. This does not however retract from the overall plot of the story which is embarking on a quest to save humanity.

name: Tenet
review: Extremely mind boggling movie by Nolan, which makes the plot of Inception seem very simple. Even after multiple watches I am still trying to understand parts of the plot. However the thought required to understand the movies makes it extremely enganging. I especially like the protagonist of the movie, whose name we also don't know and goes by 'The Protagonist'. The action scenes were amazing because I could never have visualised how a fight between 2 beings going in the opposite direction of time could work.

name: Inception
review: Amazingly complex plot that still somehow seems believable and emotional at the end. The soundtrack is also great.

reviewSubItems.name: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone
Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban
Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire
Harry Potter and the Order of Phoenix
Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 1
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows Part 2

name: Eragon
review: Not very memorable and does 0 justice to the books and story. All the races look human so there is no immersion on that part. There was a future TV show announced which I am extremely hyped for.

name: Top Gun: Maverick
review: A simple yet extremely engaging plot with very immersive action. There was no point in this movie that was boring.

name: The Da Vinci Code
review: Always great watching a Tom Hanks movie. The puzzle solving and mystery in this movie (which is assume is based off the book that I haven't read) is really engaging.

name: A Man Called Otto
review: Fairly simple but wholesome movie. The relationships between the characters is the best part. I wouldn't rewatch it but definitely a worthwhile first watch.

The cinematography works so well with the story. The effect of one long shot makes the movie very immersive as we can feel all the action happening in real time, rather than having time jumps that is usually the case in other war movies.

name: The Last Kingdom: Seven Kings Must Die
Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice
Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children

reviewSubItems.name: Puss in Boots: The Last Wish

name: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story
A Beautiful Mind
review: This was an enjoyable movie to watch, and I went in without any knowledge of what it would be about. So the plot twist that happens in the middle of movie took me by complete surprise and made me question just how much of the narrative was a hallucination by the Protagonist. It's interesting to see how the mental issues are illustrated and the way it affects the main character and the people around him.

name: Diary of a Wimpy Kid
review: This is definitely more for a younger audience which is when I used to read these books a lot. But I always enjoyed them because of how short and easy they were with great illustrations. It's also interesting to notice how my view of Greg changed as I grew older. I used to root for Greg a lot because of how he portrayed himself always being in the right and that everything that happened to him was unjust and unfair. But later on you realise he's quite an unrealiable narrator and sociopath. Especially in how he treats and views others even if they're just being reasonable.

name: Archie Comics
review: Fun comics to read and pass the time. They're pretty light hearted and original. It also doesn't matter which order you read it in because they're mostly self-contained so they can be enjoyed by anyone.

name: The Karate Kid
review: Really great series overall with likeable characters that you can root for. The characters are also engaging, especially the main character who has a lot of flaws that he slowly overcomes.

name: Game of Thrones
review: This could have been a 10/10 show if the quality of the later seasons was as good as seasons 1-4. Those earlier seasons were very well adapted despite the extreme complexities of the plots in the books. They did of course have to cut down on details in order to keep the seasons of a reasonable length. Season 4 was definitely the peak. I think it starts going downhill when the showrunners diverged from the book content or ran out of books. The characters became very 1-dimensional and often lost all the development they had gone through. Jaime is a great example of this.

name: House of the Dragon
review: Only 1 season has come out but I really enjoyed the show, being a big fan of the book. It's interesting to see just how much life and details they brought into the characters who were mainly just depicted from a more 'historical' view. The performance of Viserys was definitely the highlight of the season. I am looking forward to future seasons if they can keep the same level of quality as this first season.

name: Minecraft
review: One of the best games i've ever played, because you can do whatever you want in it and build whatever you want. The first version I ever played was the early pocket edition version. Although this was much more limited in features it was really fun playing LAN multiplayer. I later got the PC Java version on which i've had the most fun ever. Playing on a multiplayer server with friends is the best part of this game. Being able to build bases together and share resources. There are so many complex mechanics and an entire automation system which has infinite potential.

name: The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild
Project Zomboid
review: Objectively this game is definitely great with the survival mechanics and depth, but it's not the type of game I'd enjoy.

reviewSubItems.name: Mario Kart DS
review: This was my first ever Mario Kart game so it has high nostalgia value. I played plenty of local multiplayer battles and the skill cap with the game could get quite high with the drifting mechanics.

reviewSubItems.name: Mario Kart Wii
review: The hardest Mario Kart game i've played. I think this is due to the lower precision of the Wii remote which relies on tilting to steer. This leads for some really funny multiplayer moments where you can go from first to last right before the finish line. Overall, I like the maps on this the best.

reviewSubItems.name: Mario Kart 8
review: The best looking Mario Kart game. The underwater and hover sections of races are great and the maps are fun. There is also a steering assist mode for beginners which makes steering easier.

name: Mario & Sonic at the Olympic Games (Wii)
Pokemon Heartgold
review: The first ever pokemon game that I played, so that also made it my favourite. I really enjoyed the Jhoto region and taking the journey across it. My favourite part is definitely Golden Rod city and the Pokéathlon Dome which I spent a lot of time at.

name: Pokemon Emerald
review: I played this on a GBA Emulator and it was also a great pokemon game, although I still find Pokemon Heartgold to be the best.

name: Super Mario Odyssey
review: I've been wanting to play this for a long time as I only recently got the Switch console in 2023. This game definitely lives up to the hype. The wide variety of different worlds is amazing. The cappy mechanic is really fun and allows for some neat parkour tricks which can get you to places that don't seem reachable.

name: Percy Jackson and the Olympians
review: The OG series that started it all. This series has amazing re-readability and is also easy to read because of the more casual and less serious tone of the main protagonist. Percy Jackson is an extremely likeable character that is easy to root for because of his traits to help his friends and find a way through any problem.

name: Bullet Train
review: I went in without any prior knowledge so I was expecting a more serious movie based on the first few minutes but the movie turned out to be quite fun. It had some emotional moments but for the most part the humour was funny and didn't take itself too seriously. There was also a lot of appearances from famous actors which I wasn't expecting. The CGI isn't too good at times but was enough to keep the immersion. Overall it's a good watch if you're not looking for a serious or deep movie to pass the time.

name: Back to the Future
review: Such an amazing classic that is really rewatchable. The main characters are super likeable and the plot is very fun to follow and fits in with the slightly exaggerated acting of Marty and Doc. The theme music is also very iconic.

name: Air
review: Really solid and entertaining movie. Although the plot was pretty simple and contained, the performances and humour between the characters was amazing, especially Matt Damon's performance.

name: Memento
review: Finally go around to watching this Nolan movie and I wasn't disappointed. It's a really creative concept that starts off confusing but makes more sense as the movie progresses. It's interesting to see how a movie can be told in a reverse yet still linear order. Furthermore the characters who we initially believe to be the most suspicious end up being less suspicious as we go back in time which shows how the supposed protagonist spirals into a loop of feeding himself misinformation. The plot twist involving Sammy Jenkins also reminded me of Shutter Island, and how we the viewers also fall into the lies the unrealiable main character has created.

name: Diablo IV
review: My first ever experience with an action rpg and I am finding it really fun. The environment and graphics are amazing and the story is also quite engaging, although slow at the start. The immersion does get broken sometimes due to performance and network issues, however the game is still really enjoyable. For a casual to semi-hardcore gamer there is a lot of content and variety to do which is also made more fun with parties and multiplayer events.

reviewSubItems.name: Into the Spider-Verse
review: The music and art style is amazing and the story was very engaging.

reviewSubItems.name: Across the Spider-Verse
review: Even better than the first movie. Every scene felt really deep and there was a lot of emotional moments that was complemented very well with the art style. It's cool to see how so many art styles can be used in a single movie but still remain very coherent. My favourite scene in the movie was the elevator scene.
